newsitem.title: JAPAN: BOJ introduction of RTGS includes JGB settlement.
newsitem.headline: BOJ introduction of RTGS includes JGB settlement.

text.p: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) said on Tuesday its planned introduction of the Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system for financial institutions with accounts at the BOJ will include yen bond transactions.

The BOJ announced a framework on the introduction of the RTGS after gathering suggestions from the financial institutions since December, but the bank said it was still a "skeleton" plan that may need further adjustments.
The BOJ said given strong supports, it would, as planned, introduce the RTGS system by the year 2000.
Japanese government bond transactions would not be excluded, the bank said. They are currently settled once a day at 3 p.m. through checking accounts at the BOJ.
The BOJ's Delivery Versus Payment (DVP) system, under which JGB transactions are currently settled, only reduces a time gap between money transactions and delivery of the bonds.

The BOJ also said if a fund shortage occurred, it would provide liquidity by allowing overdrafts without interest payments, adding that there would be no limit for fund supply to each borrower for the time being.
The bank has said the biggest obstacle to the introduction of RTGS is that it would require more liquidity than the current system.

The RTGS would allow the financial institutions to settle transactions on a real-time basis, whereas under the current system transactions are settled at four specific points within a business day -- 9 a.m., 1 p.m., 3 p.m. and 5 p.m. -- through the accounts that the institutions have at the BOJ.

The current system is efficient as long as there is no bank failure. But once there are any defaults, all transactions would need to be halted, paralysing the entire system. -- Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-33432-8570
